003 * image processing published by Springer-Verlag in various languages and editions.

006 * Copyright (c) 2006-2022 Wilhelm Burger, Mark J. Burge. 
007 * All rights reserved. Visit https://imagingbook.com for additional details.
008 *******************************************************************************/
009package imagingbook.common.util;
010
011import java.util.stream.IntStream;
012
013/**
014 * <p>
015 * Determines the 'permutation' of a sequence of numbers and
016 * keeps it as an array ({@link #perm}) of position indexes.
017 * These indexes indicate how the original input array
018 * may be re-ordered to become sorted
019 * (see {@link #getPermutation()}).
020 * </p>
021 * 
022 * <p>
023 * Usage example: Get the second-smallest element in some array
024 * {@code double[] A}:
025 * </p>
026 * <pre>
027 * int k = SortMap.getNthSmallestIndex(A, 1);
028 * double x = A[k];</pre>
029 * <p>or, directly,</p>
030 * <pre>
031 * double x = getNthSmallestValue(A, 1);</pre>
032 * 
033 * @author WB
034 *
035 */
036public class SortMap {
037        
038        private final int[] perm;
039        
040        /**
041         * Constructor for {@code double[]}. The input array is not modified.
042         * @param numbers the input array
043         */
044        public SortMap(double[] numbers) {
045                this.perm = IntStream.range(0, numbers.length).boxed()
046                        .sorted((i, j) -> Double.compare(numbers[i], numbers[j]))
047                        .mapToInt(x->x.intValue()).toArray();
048        }
049        
050        /**
051         * Constructor for {@code float[]}. The input array is not modified.
052         * @param numbers the input array
053         */
054        public SortMap(float[] numbers) {
055                this.perm = IntStream.range(0, numbers.length).boxed()
056                        .sorted((i, j) -> Float.compare(numbers[i], numbers[j]))
057                        .mapToInt(x->x.intValue()).toArray();
058        }
059        
060        /**
061         * Constructor for {@code int[]}. The input array is not modified.
062         * @param numbers the input array
063         */
064        public SortMap(int[] numbers) {
065                this.perm = IntStream.range(0, numbers.length).boxed()
066                        .sorted((i, j) -> Integer.compare(numbers[i], numbers[j]))
067                        .mapToInt(x->x.intValue()).toArray();
068        }
069        
070        // --------------------------------------------------
071        
072        /**
073         * Returns the permutation (position indexes) for the underlying
074         * number sequence as a {@code int} array.
075         * That is, the first value in the returned array is the index
076         * of the smallest element in {@code numbers}, the second element
077         * points to the second-smallest element, etc.
078         * For example, if the original number sequence (passed to the constructor) is
079         * <pre>
080         * double[] A = {50.0, 20.0, 100.0, 120.0, 40.0, -10.0};</pre>
081         * then the index array produced by 
082         * <pre>int[] perm = new SortMap(A).getPermutation();</pre> contains
083         * {@code (5, 1, 4, 0, 2, 3)}.
084         * This means that 
085         * <pre>A[perm[i]] &le; A[perm[i+1]]</pre>
086         * and thus the sequence
087         * <pre>{A[perm[0]], A[perm[1]],..., A[perm[N-1]]}</pre>
088         * is sorted.
089         * 
090         * @return the sorting map (permutation)
091         */
092        public int[] getPermutation() {
093                return this.perm;
094        }
095        
096        /**
097         * Returns the index of the n-th smallest element of the original number sequence
098         * (passed to the constructor),
099         * starting with {@code n = 0}, which returns the index of the smallest element.
100         * 
101         * @param n the index
102         * @return the index of the n-th smallest element in the original number sequence
103         */
104        public int getIndex(int n) {
105                if (n < 0 || n >= perm.length) {
106                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("position index n out of range: " + n);
107                }
108                return perm[n];
109        }
110        
111        // --------------------------------------------------
112        
113        /**
114         * Returns the nth smallest element of the specified  {@code double[]},
115         * starting with {@code n = 0}, which returns the smallest element of {@code numbers}.
116         * 
117         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
118         * @param n the index
119         * @return the n-th smallest element of {@code numbers}
120         */
121        public static double getNthSmallestValue(double[] numbers, int n) {
122                return numbers[getNthSmallestIndex(numbers, n)];
123        }
124        
125        public static int getNthSmallestIndex(double[] numbers, int n) {
126                return new SortMap(numbers).getIndex(n);
127        }
128        
129        public static double getLargestValue(double[] numbers) {
130                return numbers[getLargestIndex(numbers)];
131        }
132        
133        public static int getLargestIndex(double[] numbers) {
134                return getNthSmallestIndex(numbers, numbers.length - 1);
135        }
136        
137        /**
138         * Returns the nth smallest element of the specified {@code float[]},
139         * starting with {@code n = 0}, which returns the smallest element of {@code numbers}.
140         * 
141         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
142         * @param n the index
143         * @return the n-th smallest element of {@code numbers}
144         */
145        public static float getNthSmallestValue(float[] numbers, int n) {
146                return numbers[getNthSmallestIndex(numbers, n)];
147        }
148        
149        public static int getNthSmallestIndex(float[] numbers, int n) {
150                return new SortMap(numbers).getIndex(n);
151        }
152        
153        public static float getLargestValue(float[] numbers) {
154                return numbers[getLargestIndex(numbers)];
155        }
156        
157        public static int getLargestIndex(float[] numbers) {
158                return getNthSmallestIndex(numbers, numbers.length - 1);
159        }
160        
161        /**
162         * Returns the nth smallest element of the specified {@code int[]},
163         * starting with {@code n = 0}, which returns the smallest element of {@code numbers}.
164         * 
165         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
166         * @param n the index
167         * @return the n-th smallest element of {@code numbers}
168         */
169        public static int getNthSmallestValue(int[] numbers, int n) {
170                return numbers[getNthSmallestIndex(numbers, n)];
171        }
172        
173        public static int getNthSmallestIndex(int[] numbers, int n) {
174                return new SortMap(numbers).getIndex(n);
175        }
176        
177        public static float getLargestValue(int[] numbers) {
178                return numbers[getLargestIndex(numbers)];
179        }
180        
181        public static int getLargestIndex(int[] numbers) {
182                return getNthSmallestIndex(numbers, numbers.length - 1);
183        }
184        
185}
